completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: A ­­ a court can certainly make the determination of whether or not they have provided complete relief. In a case like this where you're dealing with liquidated damages, that's easy. It's just ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
completeLines.speech: By the way, you called this a "freestanding offer," but I have it right here, and the ­­ offer says, "Offer of judgment pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 68." This was your client's submission.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: No ­­ well, you're right, Your Honor. That's the Rule 68 offer. The other thing about Rule 68 is it's really not designed for the situation of complete relief. Defendant has offered everything, and the plaintiff ­­

completeLines.speech: Suppose one day after the offer the defendant defaulted. Would a case that's now ­­ was once moot now become non­moot?

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: Well, and that would be an unusual situation if it did, Your Honor. I think ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KENNEDY
completeLines.speech: It happened in Kokkonen. We had a case on it here in the Court.

completeLines.speech: But Mr. Garre ­­

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: ­­ plaintiff was seeking.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: ­­ and this is very much along the same lines ­­ you know, you ­­ you have an old English case. completeLines.speech: Well, but I ­­ I said that mootness is not the appropriate remedy in that case. completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: And ­­ and I think here ­­ I mean, once we're at the point where we realize this case can't ­­ can't go on any further because he's been offered everything as the case comes to this Court, then the ­­ then the question for the Court is, well, how do we dispose of it? completeLines.speech: Well, it doesn't become moot. It's just been decided. It's ­­ there's been an adjudication at that point.

completeLines.speaker: GARRE
completeLines.speech: No, there hasn't been ­­

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE KAGAN
completeLines.speech: There's nothing to dismiss.

completeLines.speaker: JUSTICE GINSBURG
completeLines.speech: That's ­­

completeLines.speech: That's not an appropriate determination of Article III.

completeLines.speech: How could he file a class action on your theory? That's what he wanted to do, and he was stopped very early on by this offer of judgment.
